misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing mental model for Java arrays
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index arraySize), and that looping from 1..arraySize is the natural/correct way to access all elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..arraySize-1. Using 1..arraySize attempts to access index arraySize, which is out of bounds, and it also skips index 0 entirely. This affects input, shifting, and printing. The correct wrap-right shift must treat last element as index arraySize-1 and first as index 0.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input (and also during shifting/printing if it somehow got past input). Program does not produce the required output.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way
userInputArray[currentIndex] = userInputValue; // I think index currentIndex should match the element number
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start at 1, and that the last element of an array of size N is located at index N. They think 'human-style counting' (starting from 1) should map directly to array indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array of size N has valid indices 0 through N-1. The first element is at index 0, and the last element is at index N-1. By treating index 1 as the first position and index arraySize as the last position, the student skips index 0 entirely and attempts to access an invalid index (arraySize), causing an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when attempting to read userInputArray[arraySize] or when accessing userInputArray[1] during the shift operation. Even if the code compiles, it will crash at runtime.

evidence.code_snippet: int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices start at 1 and end at the value of the array's size, mirroring human-centric counting rather than the zero-based indexing used in programming.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are zero-indexed, meaning valid indices range from 0 to length - 1. The student attempts to access index N in an array of size N, which causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and ignores index 0 entirely.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing in Java arrays (confusing human counting with valid indices)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays start at index 1 (so the “first element” is at position 1 and the “last element” is at position N), and that using arraySize as an index refers to the last element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: for an array of length N, valid indices are 0..N-1. Using indices 1..N will skip index 0 and attempt to access index N, which is out of bounds. This affects input, shifting, and printing: the program should store/read/print using 0..arraySize-1, and the wrap-around should move the original last element (index arraySize-1) into index 0.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) for any arraySize > 0; therefore the program does not produce the required shifted output.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way
userInputArray[currentIndex] = userInputValue; // ... index currentIndex should match the element number
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are 1-indexed (like human counting), so the first element is at position 1, the second at position 2, and the last element at position N (where N is the array size). The student treats array indices as if they correspond directly to element numbers in the way a person would count them (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use 0-based indexing. Valid indices for an array of size N range from 0 to N-1. The first element is at index 0, and the last element is at index N-1. The student's mental model incorrectly maps human counting (1, 2, 3, ..., N) to array indices, causing access attempts to invalid positions that are either out of bounds or skip the actual first element.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. When arraySize=4, the code attempts to access userInputArray[4] (which doesn't exist), and also skips userInputArray[0] entirely, leaving it uninitialized. The array only has valid indices 0-3.

evidence.code_snippet: int currentIndex = 1; // I will start from 1 because I want to count all elements in a human way
userInputArray[currentIndex] = userInputValue; // I think index currentIndex should match the element number
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySize]; // attempts to access index 4 when only 0-3 exist
int shiftIndex = arraySize; // I believe the last position is arraySize
userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder; // places at position 1 instead of 0
int printIndex = 1; // Start from 1 because I think the first element is at position 1

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start at 1 and terminate at the literal value of the array's size, mirroring human-centric counting rather than zero-based indexing.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Accessing index N results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and index 0 is left unutilized.
